The mixture turned a milky, translucent white. They had a working time of thirty minutes before it would begin to set. There was no time to waste.

With a shared, silent nod, they tipped the bucket. The liquid silicone flowed into the mould with a thick, satisfying slowness, filling the negative space of the clay impression, covering the intricate details she had so carefully captured. It crept into every corner of the melamine box, a pristine white flood that promised either salvation or financial ruin. Once it was poured, there was nothing more to do. The chemical reaction had begun, and the outcome was now out of their hands. The data sheet recommended a twenty-four-hour cure time. A full day of waiting. A full day of not knowing. The silence in the shop was heavy with the weight of their gamble. As if on cue, the door creaked open and Shirley Henderson bustled in, her tartan flask in hand. “Goodness me, you two look like you’ve just seen a ghost!” she declared cheerfully, utterly oblivious to the high-stakes chemistry experiment curing on the workbench. “Nothing a good cup of tea won’t fix.” Her mundane, comforting presence was so jarringly normal that Maia let out a laugh that was dangerously close to a sob.

The tea was sweet, milky, and absurdly normal. Shirley chattered on about the upcoming village fête and the deplorable state of the petunias in the public planters, her cheerful monologue a protective bubble around Maia and Liam’s silent, screaming tension. They sipped their tea, nodding in the right places, their eyes repeatedly flicking to the workbench where the white liquid sat, placid and inscrutable. It was a surreal pantomime of civility. At one point, Shirley gestured towards the wall with her cup. “Agnes always said the secret to a good business was good bones. She meant the shop, of course, but I think she meant people, too. Sturdy stock, she’d say.” The innocent remark landed with the weight of prophecy. Maia looked at Liam, his face grimy but his posture solid and unwavering, and felt a surge of something stronger than hope: gratitude. She wasn't facing this alone. When Shirley finally bustled out, leaving them with two empty cups and a plate of scone crumbs, the silence that descended was no longer one of despair. It was the quiet of a team before a big game, focused and ready.

Liam broke it first, his voice low and practical. “Okay. We have twenty-four hours to kill. We can’t watch it cure. That’s like watching a pot to make it boil. We need to work.” He walked to the corner where they had stacked cans of paint and rollers. “The electrician is coming in two days to start the rough-in. He needs clean walls. So today, we paint.” The task was brilliantly chosen. It was large, physical, and transformative. It was something they could control. They pryed open the large tins of white paint, the clean, chemical smell cutting through the dust. They poured the thick, creamy liquid into trays and began to roll it onto the dirty, patched-up walls. The first stroke of white against the grimy cream was a revelation. It was a fresh start, a blank page. The simple, repetitive motion of rolling the paint up and down the walls became a form of meditation. It was mindless, rhythmic work that occupied their bodies and freed their minds from the frantic what-ifs. They worked in a comfortable, practiced silence, the only sounds the soft whir of the rollers and the occasional clatter of a paint tray. With every section of wall they covered, the space brightened, the years of neglect and grime disappearing under a clean, optimistic coat of white. They were literally building her blank canvas.

The long day bled into a long, sleepless night for Maia. She went back to her tiny flat, but the silence there was different from the productive quiet of the shop. It was empty and loud with her own anxieties. She lay awake, picturing the silicone mixture at a molecular level, imagining bubbles forming, weak spots appearing, the chemical reaction failing. She imagined peeling it away to find a sticky, useless mess. By dawn, she had convinced herself of their failure. She arrived back at the shop haggard and hollow-eyed, expecting to find Liam equally on edge. Instead, she found him already there, calmly sanding a piece of timber he had salvaged from the demolition pile, planning to repurpose it as a shelf. He took one look at her face, handed her a coffee, and simply said, “Almost time.” His steadiness was an anchor. The shop, now gleaming with its first coat of pristine white paint, felt different. It was brighter, cleaner, and full of a quiet, waiting potential. It looked like a place where good things could happen. The twenty-four hours were up.

They approached the workbench with the reverence of priests approaching an altar. The silicone in the melamine box was no longer liquid. It was a solid, opaque block of milky white, smooth and firm to the touch. It had set. That was the first hurdle cleared. The next was demoulding it without tearing it. Liam worked with the painstaking care of a surgeon, using a screwdriver to gently pry the sides of the melamine box away. The wood splintered and cracked, but the silicone inside remained pristine. With the sides removed, all that was left was to peel the original clay impression from the newly formed gasket. This was Maia’s job. Her fingers, trembling slightly, found an edge. Holding her breath, she began to lift. The clay, now dry and brittle, came away cleanly, revealing the intricate, perfect negative of the shape beneath. The newly created gasket lay on the bench, a long, flexible, impossibly perfect replica of the channel it was designed to fill. It was smooth, flawless, and free of a single air bubble. It was beautiful.

Now for the final, terrifying test. Maia lifted the gasket. It felt supple and strong in her hands, a bizarre and wonderful creation born of their shared desperation. She carried it to the oven, her heart pounding a frantic rhythm against her ribs. She lined it up with the empty channel in the oven door frame. With gentle pressure from her fingertips, she began to press it into place. It slid into the groove as if it were made for it, a perfect, snug fit. It was a moment of pure, unadulterated magic. She ran her finger along its length, the smooth, resilient rubber a testament to their insane gamble. She stepped back. Liam reached out and slowly, deliberately, closed the heavy oven door. Instead of the loose, metallic rattle it had made before, it closed with a soft, solid, deeply satisfying *thump*. There was no give, no wobble. It was sealed. But they needed to be sure. Liam pulled the same crisp ten-dollar note from his wallet, the one that had started this whole ordeal. He slid it halfway into the doorframe and closed the door on it. He tugged gently. The note held fast. He tugged harder. It wouldn't budge. He looked at Maia, his face, for once, utterly devoid of its usual cynical humour, and broke into a grin so wide it seemed to light up the entire room.

A choked, hysterical laugh bubbled up out of Maia’s chest, a sound of pure, unadulterated relief that echoed in the newly painted space. She threw her arms around Liam’s neck, burying her face in his dusty, paint-splattered shoulder as he hugged her back, lifting her off the ground in a triumphant, spinning circle. They had done it. They had faced an impossible, budget-destroying problem and had solved it not with money, but with ingenuity, desperation, and a trust in each other’s skills. The oven, which had been a symbol of her recklessness and looming failure, was now a monument to her resilience. Standing in the bright, white room, surrounded by the tools she had fought for, with the heart of her kitchen now beating strong and true, she knew with a certainty that reached down to her bones that she would not fail. The Gable was going to be real.
